headline.print_headline: European Official Drops Plan to Regulate Drinking More Strictly
headline.main: European Official Drops Plan to More Strictly Regulate Drinking

docs.lead_paragraph: The alcohol industry in Europe escaped stricter regulation when the European Union’s health commissioner appeared to give in to opposition from the industry.
docs.snippet: The alcohol industry in Europe escaped stricter regulation when the European Union’s health commissioner appeared to give in to opposition from the industry.

headline.print_headline: Tumor Types May Explain Survival Rates for Cancer
headline.main: Tumor Types May Explain Survival Rates for Cancer

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study suggests different survival rates for African-American women with breast cancer may arise in part from a difference in tumor biology.
docs.snippet: A new study suggests different survival rates for African-American women with breast cancer may arise in part from a difference in tumor biology.

headline.main: Tumor Types May Explain Survival Rates for Cancer

docs.abstract: Dr Wendy A Woodward, University of Texas radiation oncology assitant professor, leads study that suggests documented disparity between breast cancer survival rates of whites and Hispanics as compared to African-Americans may be result of differences in tumor biology; research is published in journal Cancer (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: African-American women with breast cancer have significantly lower survival rates compared with white or Hispanic women, and a new study suggests that one reason may be a difference in tumor biology between the races. The lower survival rates are known from previous studies, and different explanations have been offered, including lower socioeconomic status, reduced access to health care, obesity, side effects that lead to lower chemotherapy dosages, and racial bias among health care professionals.
docs.snippet: African-American women with breast cancer have significantly lower survival rates compared with white or Hispanic women, and a new study suggests that one reason may be a difference in tumor biology between the races.     The lower survival rates are...

headline.print_headline: It’s Healthy, but Must Kids Eat It?
headline.main: It’s Healthy, but Must Kids Eat It? (6 Letters)
It's Healthy, but Must Kids Eat It?

docs.abstract: Six letters comment on several articles about food and nutrition; Nancy Huehnergarth, prompted by Oct 18 article about new school food program in England, says England should persist with program, even through children and parents are complaining; Mara Clarke rails against decision-making power given to children; Franklin H Stone, executive director of Common Good, says physical activity must be incorporated into any program designed to increase health of children; Heather Weir, commenting on Oct 17 article about Disney plan to link marketing to nutrition, lauds program, but disagrees with certain aspects of it and suggests more attention be paid to portion control; Jamila Iris Edwards applauds idea, but suggests Disney should not be marketing food to children at all; Meredith Greif says nation must develop more healthful approach to food rather than taxing fast-food as suggested in Oct 19 Martin B Schmidt Op-Ed article
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Glorious Food? English Schoolchildren Think Not'' (Rotherham Journal, front page, Oct. 18):
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Glorious Food? English Schoolchildren Think Not'' (Rotherham Journal, front page, Oct. 18):

docs.lead_paragraph: Walter DeNino was a young lab technician who analyzed data for his mentor, Eric Poehlman. What he found was that Poehlman was not the scientist he appeared to be.
docs.snippet: Walter DeNino was a young lab technician who analyzed data for his mentor, Eric Poehlman. What he found was that Poehlman was not the scientist he appeared to be.
